pages.title: The Flu: Not Just A Bad Cold
pages.snippet:
The flu” is so common, it can’t be that bad, right?

Actually, yes, it can be that bad.

Most of us get at least a couple of colds per year. (If you have young kids around, I bet it’s a lot more!) A cold can vary from mild to miserable, but let’s face it, it’s usually more of an annoyance than anything – we gotta cover our mouth to cough, we run through crazy numbers of Kleenexes, and cough drops taste terrible. But a few days of taking it easy and we’re back to normal.

This is not the flu. The flu is not a bad cold – it’s like being hit by a truck.
pages.content:
The flu” is so common, it can’t be that bad, right?

Actually, yes, it can be that bad.

Most of us get at least a couple of colds per year. (If you have young kids around, I bet it’s a lot more!) A cold can vary from mild to miserable, but let’s face it, it’s usually more of an annoyance than anything – we gotta cover our mouth to cough, we run through crazy numbers of Kleenexes, and cough drops taste terrible. But a few days of taking it easy and we’re back to normal.

This is not the flu. The flu is not a bad cold – it’s like being hit by a truck.

We call a lot of things “the flu,” from colds to stomach bugs. But the real flu, caused by the influenza virus, causes high fevers, nasty coughs, aching all over, and getting so tired that getting out of bed to go to the bathroom might as well be climbing a mountain. Most of the time, it’s about a week of solid misery followed by more time to recover before we feel like ourselves again.

And that’s assuming we don’t develop any complications, like pneumonia or brain inflammation (encephalitis). Most healthy adults and older children who get the flu fully recover without much more than time and TLC; they can develop complications, but usually don’t. They can also spread the flu to young children, elderly people or people with medical conditions, who are at higher risk of developing these complications, which can be very dangerous and even fatal.

The symptoms of colds and the flu overlap, but with the flu symptoms tend to be much more severe. Add that to the risk of complications, and well, it’s not a bug to underestimate.

pages.title: My Personal Experiences With Vaccination
pages.snippet: I’m a family doctor, so I’m on the giving end of vaccinations on a regular basis. But I live in the world too, so I am also on the receiving end.
pages.content:
I’m a family doctor, so I’m on the giving end of vaccinations on a regular basis. But I live in the world too, so I am also on the receiving end.

First of all, yes, my own kids are fully vaccinated, including their annual flu shots. Do they like them? Well, no, that would be asking a lot. But we talk about them before the visit (there’s never a “surprise” shot), we acknowledge that it’ll hurt but try to put it in context (“it’ll be over by the time you count to three, and biting your tongue is way worse”), and in our house vaccinations are a good reason for a special treat - usually watching videos on our phones during the shot, and going for ice cream afterward. With the two-year-old, there tends to be a brief squawk, but she moves on pretty quickly. The five-year-old and the seven-year-old tend to be focused on the ice cream. We sometimes have to deal with mild fevers and grumpiness later that day, but hey, the fever from meningitis (infection around the brain) or pneumonia or the other diseases that they’re now protected from would be a lot worse. Not to mention the grumpiness.

Second, yes, I get the flu shot myself. Every year. It’s not the best vaccine out there in terms of effectiveness (70% in a good year), but it’s quite a bit better than having no vaccine and the risks are low. There are two major reasons for me to get the flu shot: first, I’m hoping to avoid the giant hassle of missing several days of work and parenting, and second, there are lots of people around me who would be at high risk of complications from the flu, and I don’t want to be the one who gives it to them if I can help it. Sure, I wash my hands all day long, but that’s only going to get me so far.

My personal experiences with vaccination have been pretty unremarkable. I or my husband or my kids get the shot. Maybe we get a sore arm afterward. My husband tends to get a bit of a fever after his flu shot. Usually by 24 hours it’s a done deal and we are back to our usual routine – dance, soccer, work, whatever. But with that little action, we’ve protected ourselves from nastiness and heartache, and we’ve helped to protect those around us who can’t protect themselves, like my eighty-year-old aunt, or a kid at school who can’t get vaccinations because she’s going through cancer treatment.

It’s a really big deal when you think about it, even if it’s a little action.

pages.snippet: A common concern about vaccines are that they might be “too many, too soon” – that all the shots can overwhelm a baby’s immune system. Sometimes parents ask about spacing out the shots or giving them separately.
pages.content:
A common concern about vaccines are that they might be “too many, too soon” – that all the shots can overwhelm a baby’s immune system. Sometimes parents ask about spacing out the shots or giving them separately.

While it’s always the parents’ decision when shots are given, the recommended vaccine schedule has been carefully thought out, and has a few important things going for it.

  • Above all else, it provides as much protection as possible, as soon as possible. Kids are left vulnerable to diseases for the shortest possible time.
  • It reduces the number of trips to the doctor, nurse or other health care provider. It’s easy to forget to come back or to get busy with other things. Plus it’s a lot of work to pack up a baby (never mind any siblings) and make the trek to the office. It’s easier for everyone if we only do that when it’s really needed.
  • It keeps the number of shots to a minimum by putting multiple vaccines into one needle. Measles, mumps, rubella and varicella, for example – one shot instead of four! These combinations have been carefully studied to show that they work AND that they’re safe.
  • Some vaccines only come in combination. You can’t get a pertussis vaccine by itself, for example, as it always comes with tetanus and diphtheria.

The problem with delaying vaccines is that it leaves kids unprotected – right when they may be most vulnerable. Pertussis [link to Pertussis page], or whooping cough, is an example; it’s miserable at any age, but the younger you are, the more dangerous (in other words, more likely to cause death) it is.

Babies’ immune systems are seeing new things (bacteria, viruses, proteins, you name it) all the time, because so many experiences are “firsts” for them. That’s not a problem – it might even help prevent allergies later on, though that’s still being studied. Immune systems need to be good at handling lots of new things at once, because that’s what they do every day!

It’s never fun to watch a baby get poked (it’s no fun giving the pokes either!) but the diseases that the vaccines prevent are way less fun, so protection is the bottom line.
